awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Mobilized Social Group Organizations Around  Per- and Polyfluoralkyl Substances
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project will examine the rapid formation of a national, networked social movement across the United States in response to industrial and military uses of per- and polyfluorinated compounds (PFASs), a class of over 3,000 chemical compounds with a broad range of adverse health outcomes. The project will examine the factors facilitating the rapid development of this movement, and the ways in which it shapes science, chemical policy, and cleanup levels. This project will provide residents and community groups affected by PFAS contamination with a greater awareness of how they can partake in the scientific process, public education, and environmental policy at local, state and federal levels. It will create greater connections among dispersed communities, and among regulators and scientists working on these issues. The project has a water testing component that will provide direct knowledge and interpretation of the extent of PFAS contamination in an impacted community, and that will be used to show how effective widely adopted remedial methods are at removing these contaminants. 

The research team will analyze the characteristics of local organizing using its Contamination Site Database, which has extensive data for 77 contaminated sites across the U.S.; new sites are to be added as they are discovered. The team will quantitatively and qualitatively assess what factors influence whether local social-movement organizations develop at a given contamination site (such as contamination characteristics, nature of media coverage, and demographics), as well as the outcomes that are achieved (such as remediation, shift in regulatory or advisory standards, and biomonitoring activities). The team will also analyze the origins, influences, priorities, and outcomes of activism by these social movement organizations by conducting 80-100 semi-structured interviews in 20-30 locations across the U.S. Team members will also use network analysis techniques on interview data and social media posts to explain and visualize how activists share information, join and expand old networks, and create new ones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mobilized Social Group Organizations Around Per- and Polyfluoralkyl Substances

This project examined the rapid and extensive development of activism in communities in the United States on per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). Since 2015, dozens of community-based social movement organizations have formed, created a national coalition, held conferences, pushed local and state officials to conduct water and blood testing, developed academic-community partnerships, helped secure federal funding for a national health study, and successfully pressured states to drastically reduce advisory levels of PFAS or create regulatory levels. We systematically studied this emerging social movement within the broader context of advocacy, research, and regulation of PFAS, using mixed qualitative methods combined with an overarching goal of developing and disseminating publicly accessible information about PFAS that was useful for PFAS-impacted communities, social scientists, and other stakeholders.

Our intellectual merit is the systematic analysis of this rapidly growing movements and its manifold set of participants. We systematically investigated this activism as a case study of new chemical class-based organizing. Our broader impacts are showing the capacity for laypeople to affect environmental policy at local, state, and federal levels; investigating activism around an entire class of hazardous chemicals; and provides a model for examining spontaneous activism. We spearheaded the organization of multi-stakeholder national PFAS conference in 2017 (140 participants), 2019 (280 participants), and 2022 (320 participants), bringing together activist groups, along with journalists, scientists, government officials, water utilities, and lawyers. Activist groups were able to coordinate at the first conference and used those connections to form the National PFAS Contamination Coalition, which currently has 39 member groups.

We conducted 94 in-depth interviews with PFAS advocates, residents, journalists, scientists, regulators, and other stakeholders, focusing on the development of their PFAS knowledge and advocacy, interactions between activism and science, and features of the PFAS contamination crisis. In a publication at Social Movement Studies, we described how advocates and residents of impacted communities engaged with scientific evidence and research processes to both use existing science and influence the direction of future research.

We developed the first nationwide database of all locations with PFAS contamination (described below), which currently contains over 1,750 sites in the United States. We used this Database to create an interactive map of PFAS contamination across the U.S. that is accessible and informative to the public. We developed a model of Presumptive PFAS Contamination to systematically and rigorously identify places where PFAS contamination was likely, in the absence of existing testing. We identified 57,412 mappable sites of presumptive contamination based on military installations, industrial codes, wastewater treatment plants, and airports. Our peer reviewed article on presumptive contamination in Environmental Science & Technology Letters received enormous mass media attention and interest from state and federal regulators, water and waste systems stakeholders, environmental and health nonprofits, and residents of PFAS-impacted communities. We continue to identify many new sources of PFAS exposure.

We have also utilized our presumptive PFAS contamination model and database of known PFAS contamination sites to investigate environmental inequalities faced by Tribal communities, carceral facilities, and communities of color. The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences requested the team to prepare an internal report on these findings, some still unpublished, for a federal interagency PFAS working group. We have provided expertise to state agencies and legislatures, to EPA headquarters and regional offices, to the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine, and to the American Association for the Advancement of Science. We provide information to many community residents who seek information on PFAS contamination.  Our website (www.pfasproject.com) has become a major national resource for the most up-to-date news on PFAS issues. In the 2021-2022 reporting period, our website received a total of approximately 139,000 views from 72,000 visitors.
